questions.question: What does Big-O notation represent in algorithm analysis?

answers.a: The exact running time in seconds
answers.b: The upper bound (worst-case) growth rate of an algorithm
answers.c: The memory usage of an algorithm
answers.d: The number of lines of code

explanations.a: Big-O does not measure exact time, it measures growth rate.
explanations.b: Correct! Big-O notation describes how the running time grows as input size increases, focusing on the worst case.
explanations.c: Big-O can describe space complexity, but primarily refers to time complexity.
explanations.d: Lines of code do not determine time complexity.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of Binary Search?

explanations.a: O(n) is the complexity of Linear Search, not Binary Search.
explanations.b: O(n²) is quadratic complexity, used in algorithms like Bubble Sort.
explanations.c: Correct! Binary Search halves the search space with each comparison, giving O(log n).
explanations.d: O(1) is constant time, Binary Search requires multiple comparisons.

questions.question: Which sorting algorithm has O(n²) time complexity in the average case?

explanations.a: Quick Sort has O(n log n) average case complexity.
explanations.b: Merge Sort has O(n log n) complexity in all cases.
explanations.c: Correct! Bubble Sort uses two nested loops, resulting in O(n²) complexity.
explanations.d: Heap Sort has O(n log n) complexity.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of multiplying two n×n matrices using the standard algorithm?

explanations.a: O(n) is linear, matrix multiplication requires more operations.
explanations.b: O(n²) is the complexity of matrix addition, not multiplication.
explanations.c: Correct! Standard matrix multiplication uses three nested loops, giving O(n³).
explanations.d: O(2ⁿ) is exponential, used in subset generation problems.

questions.question: How many subsets can be generated from a set of n elements?

explanations.a: n is just the number of elements, not subsets.
explanations.b: n² is quadratic, not related to subset count.
explanations.c: Correct! Each element can either be included or excluded, giving 2ⁿ subsets.
explanations.d: n! is the number of permutations, not subsets.

questions.question: Which of the following has the fastest growth rate?

explanations.a: O(n log n) grows slower than polynomial and exponential.
explanations.b: O(n²) is polynomial, slower than exponential.
explanations.c: Correct! Exponential O(2ⁿ) grows faster than any polynomial complexity.
explanations.d: O(n³) is polynomial, still slower than exponential.

questions.question: What is a prerequisite for Binary Search to work correctly?

answers.c: The array must have unique elements
answers.d: The array must have even number of elements

explanations.a: Binary Search requires a sorted array to work.
explanations.b: Correct! Binary Search divides the array based on comparison with middle element, which only works if the array is sorted.
explanations.c: Duplicate elements are allowed in Binary Search.
explanations.d: The number of elements does not need to be even.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of generating all permutations of n elements?

explanations.a: O(n) is linear, permutations require much more work.
explanations.b: O(n²) is quadratic, not enough for permutations.
explanations.c: O(2ⁿ) is for subset generation, not permutations.
explanations.d: Correct! There are n! (n factorial) permutations of n distinct elements.
